Award.AwardTitle: Mount Erebus Volcano Observatory: Operations, Science and Outreach (MEVO-OSO)
Award.AbstractNarration:
Intellectual Merit:
Mt. Erebus is one of only a handful of volcanoes worldwide that have lava lakes with readily observable and nearly continuous Strombolian explosive activity. Erebus is also unique in having a permanent convecting lava lake of anorthoclase phonolite magma. Over the years significant infrastructure has been established at the summit of Mt. Erebus as part of the Mount Erebus Volcano Observatory (MEVO), which serves as a natural laboratory to study a wide range of volcanic processes, especially magma degassing associated with an open convecting magma conduit. The PI proposes to continue operating MEVO for a further five years. The fundamental fundamental research objectives are: to understand diffuse flank degassing by using distributed temperature sensing and gas measurements in ice caves, to understand conduit processes, and to examine the environmental impact of volcanic emissions from Erebus on atmospheric and cryospheric environments. To examine conduit processes the PI will make simultaneous observations with video records, thermal imaging, measurements of gas emission rates and gas compositions, seismic, and infrasound data.

Broader impacts:
An important aspect of Erebus research is the education and training of students. Both graduate and undergraduate students will have the opportunity to work on MEVO data and deploy to the field site. In addition, this proposal will support a middle or high school science teacher for two field seasons. The PI will also continue working with various media organizations and filmmakers.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Erebus volcano is the southernmost active volcano in the world and the centerpiece of Ross Island, Antarctica. Nearby is McMurdo Station the hub of the U.S. Antarctic Program. The 3794 m (12,448 feet) high Erebus is unique in hosting a permanent convecting phonolite lava lake. Erebus is one of only a handful of volcanoes worldwide that have persistent lava lakes and exhibit readily observable and nearly continuous Strombolian explosive activity. Erebus volcano represents an outstanding natural laboratory to examine fundamental scientific questions, which contribute to an understanding of volcanism worldwide. Over the years a significant infrastructure was built up at the summit of Erebus volcano and known as the Mount Erebus Volcano Observatory. This was the home for the research teams as they battled the weather, the harsh environment and effects of being at high altitude. 

The project had many different research objectives, but much of the work was directed to understanding the eruptive and non-eruptive magmatic system. We used an integrated approach using various tools provided by geophysics, geochemistry and remote sensing observations. Amongst several fundamental research objectives, the most important was to understand the inner workings of this active volcano. We made simultaneous observations using video records, thermal imaging, measured gas emission rates and their compositions, used seismic and infrasound data to characterize the eruptive behavior.

To understand what volcanologists, call the plumbing (the magma storage area beneath the earth?s surface and the conduit connecting it to the lava lake), we used seismic studies. We put out 90 seismometers on the ground and then let off small explosive charges. After a lot of hard work and data analysis our seismic data gave us an image, like a CAT scan, of the volcano. Just below the surface was a reservoir of magma and this was offset to the side and not directly beneath the lava lake and this was connected to the lava lake by a sloping conduit.  We imaged the lava lake with thermal cameras and using radar and laser-based distance imaging instrumentation called lidar, we watched the lake rise and fall in a regular way, like a heart beating. Then we added remote sensing thermal infrared spectrometer to make continuous measure of the gas emitted from the lake. This also varied in a cyclical way like the surface of the lava lake. Simultaneous observations like this had never been made at a lava lake. It was exciting and still is puzzling and badly needs a mathematical model to try and understand the root cause of why Erebus breaths. What was the cause of the heartbeat? Magma is continuous circulating from the high-level magma chamber up the conduit to the lake. Within this stream of molten rock are bubbles of gas that range in size. The small bubbles drive the convection and  contribute to the heart beat. But once in a while (daily, sometimes 3 or 4 times a day) larger bubbles, that probably fill the conduit, rise rapidly and because the gas is under pressure when it reaches the surface of the lava lake it explodes in the classic Strombolian eruptions that Erebus is world renowned for.

The small Strombolian eruptions hurled large blobs of molten magma into the air, sometimes reaching over 200 meters above the crater rim and rarely these fall onto the outer slopes of the cone. The volcanic bombs provide a direct sample of the magma from the lava lake. For years we collected the bombs and analyzed them looking for changes in the magma composition. For almost 50 years of sampling no changes in the glass composition has occurred. When we analyze the lava flows that we dated in this project as being mostly in the 4 to 8-thousand-year age range, they are identical to the bombs. Erebus is a very stable volcano system. 

Inside the glassy bombs are large crystals of a sodium rich aluminum silicate mineral called anorthoclase. Almost unique in the world these crystals can reach over 10 cm (4 inches) in length. Such crystals are almost unheard-of in the lavas from the world?s active volcanoes. The anorthoclase are encased in black glistening volcanic glass but when we cut the crystals open, we see they are full of small blebs of glass (what we call melt inclusions) and these record the growth of the crystal. Why do we get such giant crystals in Erebus? Well the answer the crystals tell is that they grow by circulating around and around in the magmatic system as the magma rises by convection up into the lava lake and then driven by cooling the magma sinks back into the magma chamber. So up and down the crystals go. Each journey through the lava lake sees new growth. Much remains to be understood and we need to quantify this crystal growth.
